meanings.definition: A dry, rough protective crust that forms over a wound during healing.
meanings.sent1: After I fell and scraped my knee, a scab formed to protect the cut.
meanings.sent2: The scab on his elbow was starting to peel off as the wound healed.
meanings.sent3: The scab on the cut looked like a tiny shield guarding the injury.
meanings.sent4: Her scab was like nature's bandage, keeping the wound safe.
meanings.sent5: The scab felt rough to the touch, a sign that the healing had begun.

meanings.definition: A person who continues to work during a strike, often as a replacement for a striking worker.
meanings.sent1: During the strike, the company hired scabs to keep the business running.
meanings.sent2: The scab crossed the picket line and went to work despite the protest.
meanings.sent3: The scab worker didn't realize the tension they caused by taking the job.
meanings.sent4: Being a scab can lead to conflicts with striking employees.
meanings.sent5: The scab worker felt torn between earning a living and supporting the strike.

meanings.sent1: If you keep picking at the scab, it will take longer to heal.
meanings.sent2: His knee scabbed over quickly after the fall.
meanings.sent3: The wound began to scab over, signaling the start of the healing process.
meanings.sent4: The cut scabbed up nicely, showing that it was on the mend.
meanings.sent5: She watched as the scrape scabbed over, knowing it was getting better.
